title: How to Clean a Face Cleansing Brush

steps.title: Clean your brush every 1-2 weeks based on how often you use it.
steps.content: Clean your brush every 1-2 weeks based on how often you use it. Over time, the bristles on your brush get caked in bacteria and dead skin cells. Disconnecting the bristles and-deep cleaning your brush will remove all of the junk that builds up in the brush. Do this every 1-2 weeks to keep your brush and skin clean and safe. [1] X Research source If the bristles on the head of the brush are discolored, the brush definitely need a good deep cleaning.

steps.title: Brace the back of the brush with your nondominant hand.
steps.content: Brace the back of the brush with your nondominant hand. Take the brush off of the charger and take it to your sink. Lift it up and wrap your nondominant hand around the back of the brush’s head. Hold it firmly to brace it. Face cleansing brushes are always waterproof, but the charger is not. Never clean the brush when it’s still on the charger.

steps.title: Twist the disc attached to the bristles counterclockwise to remove it.
steps.content: Twist the disc attached to the bristles counterclockwise to remove it. The bristles are connected to a small disc that twists into the head of the brush. Wrap your free hand around this disc and hold it firmly. Rotate the disc counterclockwise until the bristles and the disc pop off of the brush. [2] X Research source This process is the same on every brand of cleansing brush. You cannot thoroughly clean your face cleansing brush without removing the disc.

steps.title: Scrub the back of the disc with hand soap and a toothbrush.
steps.content: Scrub the back of the disc with hand soap and a toothbrush. Set the body of the brush aside to clean it later. Take the bristles and flip them upside down. Squirt a small dollop of hand soap into the back of the disc and run it under water for 1-2 seconds. Scrub the back of the disc with a clean toothbrush. Use back-and-forth strokes to work the soap into the crevices of the disc. [3] X Research source You can use a cotton swab to get into the nooks and crannies if you’d like. The toothbrush usually does a good job on its own, though. The back of the disc often gets dirty because junk slips through the sides of the disc where it attaches to the brush.

steps.title: Brush around the sides of the disc with the same toothbrush.
steps.content: Brush around the sides of the disc with the same toothbrush. Take your toothbrush and run the bristles around the sides of the disc. Scrub each portion of the disc 1-2 times to remove any dirt or junk that’s sticking to the sides of the disc. [4] X Research source The sides of the disc get dirty for the same reason the underside does—dirt and dead skin get trapped in the seam where the bristles attach to the brush.

steps.title: Massage the bristles by hand using standard hand soap.
steps.content: Massage the bristles by hand using standard hand soap. Flip the disc over so the bristles are facing up and squirt a dollop of hand soap directly into the bristles. Hold the bristles under a steady stream of warm water and gently run your thumbs over them. Work your fingers through the bristles over and over to spread the soap out and clean your bristles. [5] X Expert Source Lydia Shedlofsky, DO Dermatologist Expert Interview. 3 May 2021. Do this for 1-2 minutes to remove any junk, dirt, or dead skin cells. Set the disc aside when you’re done. The bristles tend to be pretty strong, but you don’t want to massage them so hard that you bend them. Use a gentle motion to clean this part of the face cleansing brush.

steps.title: Clean the head of the brush using your toothbrush and soap.
steps.content: Clean the head of the brush using your toothbrush and soap. Pick up the body of the brush and squirt a dollop of hand soap into the opening where the disc attaches to the brush. Run the brush under water for 1-2 seconds to get it wet. Then, scrub the inside of the brush’s head with your toothbrush. Work the toothbrush’s bristles around the head 2-3 times to clean the inside of the brush. Again, you can use a cotton swab to really get into the corners if you’d like. The toothbrush on its own is probably fine, though. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Run the brush under warm water and set it aside to air dry.
steps.content: Run the brush under warm water and set it aside to air dry. Turn the warm water on and set the head of the brush underneath it. Let the water run for 15-20 seconds to rinse out all the soap. Set the brush aside and let it air dry. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse the bristles and disc under warm water and let it air out to dry.
steps.content: Rinse the bristles and disc under warm water and let it air out to dry. Once the bristles are clean, turn the disc around under the warm water. Rinse the brush for 30-45 seconds until the water runs clear and you don’t see any soap on the disc. Set the disc down with the bristles facing up and wait 2-4 hours for the disc and bristles to air dry. [8] X Research source You can wipe the handle of the brush with a dry or damp cloth to remove any oils from your skin. The handle doesn’t tend to get very dirty though, so you don’t really need to do this every time you clean the brush.

steps.title: Submerge the bristles in rubbing alcohol if they’re really dirty.
steps.content: Submerge the bristles in rubbing alcohol if they’re really dirty. In most cases, hand-washing is fine for a normal cleaning. However, if your bristles are really dirty or they’re still discolored after you hand-washed them, soaking the bristles in rubbing alcohol is a great way to refresh and clean them. [9] X Research source If you use the brush every day, you may want to do this every 1-2 weeks just to sanitize the bristles.

steps.title: Fill a small container with rubbing alcohol.
steps.content: Fill a small container with rubbing alcohol. Grab a plastic or glass container big enough to completely submerge the disc and bristles. Set it down in your sink and fill it with enough rubbing alcohol to completely cover the brush. [10] X Research source You can use white vinegar instead of rubbing alcohol if you prefer. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Let the bristles soak for 10 minutes to 24 hours until the bristles are clean.
steps.content: Let the bristles soak for 10 minutes to 24 hours until the bristles are clean. Take the disc and drop it into the container. It doesn’t matter if the bristles face up or down. You can soak the disc and bristles for anywhere from 5 minutes to 24 hours. It’s really up to how discolored the bristles are and how much time you have on your hands. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the disc and rinse it off under warm water for 2-3 minutes.
steps.content: Remove the disc and rinse it off under warm water for 2-3 minutes. Put some nitrile gloves on to protect your hands from the rubbing alcohol. Lift the disc and bristles out of the rubbing alcohol by hand. Turn the sink on and rinse the bristles and disc under warm water. Rotate it under the steady stream of water to rinse off all of the rubbing alcohol. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Let the bristles air dry for 2-4 hours before reassembling the brush.
steps.content: Let the bristles air dry for 2-4 hours before reassembling the brush. Set the bristles down on a dry cloth with the bristles facing up. Let the disc air dry for a few hours before reattaching it to your brush.
